td.h2: Protecting Our Students and Community from Coronavirus

td.h3: Schools Closed for the 2019-2020 School Year
td.p: Dear School District of Niagara families,

The health and safety of our students and staff are always our number one priority. We are closing our school buildings under order to help contain the spread of COVID-19, the coronavirus in Wisconsin. We know that keeping children at home may cause difficulties for your children and families as you juggle work, child care and other challenges, and our staff are committed to doing everything we can to help make this as positive an experience as possible for your children.

Gov. Tony Evers on March 13, 2020 ordered the closure of all K-12 Wisconsin schools, public and private, from Wednesday, March 18 to April 5, as part of the state's efforts to respond to and contain COVID-19. The announcement affects almost 855,000 students in more than 400 districts across the state - and adds Wisconsin to a growing list of states to close schools.

“Kids and families across Wisconsin often depend on our schools to access food and care," Evers said. "We are going to continue working to do everything we can to ensure kids and families have the resources and support they need while schools are closed.”
The School District of Niagara will be closed from March 17 through the rest of the 2019-2020 school year. All after-school activities and athletics, including practices, also will be canceled.

The School District of Niagara would like to know if you will be in need of breakfast and lunch for your children during the time off due to COVID-19. We will continue to offer food service and delivery through the school’s 2019-2020 calendar year. Please be aware of all notifications and changes that may come from the district. We appreciate your patience and cooperation as we all get through these trying times.

Students or parents are allowed to pick-up meals at a designated location but are not to consume the meal on site. We ask that an adult or responsible student meet the school delivery vehicle or bus at the indicated delivery location. You must be home and able to accept delivery, meals will not be left unattended. We are not able to accommodate individual dietary needs.
Anticipated pickup time will be at 9:30 am in the high school commons area. If delivery is needed, school staff will leave the district at 9:00 am and begin dropping off at homes.

An email was sent to you regarding these meals.
Please respond to survey@niagara.k12.wi.us with the following information:

li.p: Will you take advantage of breakfast and lunch pickup?
Will you take advantage of breakfast and lunch delivery?
We will not need food service for your children on the mentioned dates?

td.p: Family name: _____________________ Number of meals needed: ____________
If you did not receive the email, you can contact the school at 715-251-4541.

The district will work to ensure virtual learning continues for students. Devices will be able for students to check out. If your student is in need of a device, please contact the school. 715-251-4541
Some internet carriers are offering free and/or low cost options that your family may be able to use.

Nsight Telservices is committed to supporting its neighbors during these times of uncertainty with free access to internet for households in need. Residents in the Nsight Telservices service area who do not have an existing Nsight Telservices connection can receive free service and WiFi free for two months. To enroll, call 800-826-5215. Installation fees will be waived for these households. Nsight Telservices offers internet in the greater Pulaski, Newton, Newtonburg, Niagara and Abrams communities. The Nsight Telservices network has the capacity to handle the households in our service area, including the anticipated additional use that’s expected as students and remote workers access the network. Speeds vary based on the distance from network equipment, but Nsight Telservices All-Out internet packages deliver the fastest speed available to a home. There are no data caps on the home internet product. As the community works to limit the spread of the coronavirus, Nsight Telservices is proud to support its community and provide a way for families to stay connected.

Spectrum is offering free broadband internet and WiFi access for 60 days to families with K-12 and college students. Charter, which operates Spectrum internet, said they will also waive installation fees for new households. Learn more about the Spectrum offer here or call 844-488-8395.
Comcast Internet Essentials indicated that they are providing 60 days of free internet to qualifying families. Learn more about the Comcast offer.
For students with Special Education needs, please contact our Special Education/Pupil Services Director Terry Hanson at 715-251-4541 ext 125 or email thanson@niagara.k12.wi.us.

td.div: The safety of our students and staff is our top priority. When school resumes, please watch for the following symptoms. Keep students home from school and contact their physician to ask to be tested for Coronavirus if they have these symptoms:
td.p: Please contact the school at 715-251-4541 to report the absence and symptoms. Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of Coronavirus at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) website. Those at highest risk for Coronavirus complications are older adults and individuals with compromised immune systems or heart, lung and kidney disease. See how Coronavirus is spread. It can take two to 14 days for a person to develop symptoms after initial exposure to the virus; the average is about five days.

p.strong: We have no known cases of COVID-19 among students or staff in the School District of Niagara

td.p: We continue to closely monitor the situation with our School Nurses and Marinette County Health Departments, as well as review updates from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Department of Public Instruction and the CDC. Here is the latest information on confirmed cases in Wisconsin - in Dane, Fond Du Lac, Milwaukee, Outagamie, Pierce, Racine, Sheboygan, Waukesha, Winnebago and Wood counties. Another 37 WI residents returned March 16 from a cruise where they may have been exposed and will be self-quarantined for 14 days.

img.alt: How to Prevent the Spread of Germs

h3.b: What You Can Do and Our Cleaning Measures

td.p: The School District of Niagara has a routine cleaning regimen in place to help reduce the spread of germs and communicable disease. In addition to our regular cleaning and disinfection, we are increasing the cleaning of high-touch areas and hard and soft surface items throughout the day. We will follow all guidelines of the CDC and our local and state health departments.
td.div: We all play a role in helping reduce the spread of communicable disease. We are asking our students, staff and families to practice regular preventive actions (see flyer in English, Spanish, Hmong and Mandarin Chinese) including:

ul.li: Wash your hands regularly, for 20 seconds, using soap and hot water. Make sure to wash your fingertips. This is especially important after using the restroom, coughing or sneezing into your hands, and before preparing or consuming food.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don’t have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.

If children are feeling sick, please keep them home from school. Families should have a plan in place for keeping your child home, picking up your child if they are sent home sick, and if schools are closed.

td.p: This is a rapidly evolving situation, with the World Health Organization declaring Coronavirus a pandemic, the President and Governor declaring it a public health emergency and the President issuing a month-long ban effective March 13 on all travel from Europe, including the UK and Ireland, to the U.S.
td.div: The state of Wisconsin Department of Health Services (DHS) is asking schools and organizations to:

ul.li: Avoid traveling to areas in the US with sustained community transmission of COVID-19 (currently Washington, New York, and California). See map of US sustained community transmission of COVID-19.
Self-quarantine for 14 days upon return for anyone who travels to any U.S. states with confirmed community spread of COVID-19.

td.p: Many families have travel plans for spring break. If your family is planning to travel to a country with a Level 3 travel health notice, please contact the school nurse Bill Moreau 715-251-4541 ext 231 before returning to school. The CDC is asking you to self-quarantine for 14 days. Read more about travel on the CDC's website.

We appreciate your patience with this fluid situation and we will continue to update you as needed. Please rest assured that we will continue to put your students’ safety first. If you have any questions, reach out to Bill Moreau at 715-251-4541 ext 231 or wmoreau@niagara.k12.wi.us.
